docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor whose challenge to a state abortion law led the United States Supreme Court to overturn it told a judge today that the University of Nebraska wrongfully terminated his faculty position because of political pressure. The doctor, LeRoy Carhart, performed abortions and donated fetal tissue to the university for research. After it was reported in November 1999 that the university was using fetal tissue in research, Dr. Carhart said, school officials told him they were under increasing pressure to have him resign or to terminate his unpaid position.
docs.abstract: LeRoy Carhart, doctor whose challenge to Nebraska abortion law led US Supreme Court to overturn it, tells judge University of Nebraska wrongfully terminated his faculty position because of political pressure; requests injunction ordering his reinstatement pending trial on his lawsuit against university officials; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: We all grew up knowing that carrots are good for our eyes. Carrots, among other deeply colored vegetables and fruits, are rich sources of beta carotene, the plant-based building block for vitamin A, which is required to form the visual pigment rhodopsin that allows people to see in the dark. One eventual consequence of a chronic vitamin A deficiency is night blindness, which remains a scourge among children in many poor countries and sometimes among poorly nourished children in this country.

headline.main: Unveiling a New Arsenal for Eye Health

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on influence of diet on vision; discusses nutrients that are important for eye health and their sources (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students identify the medicinal benefits, and ill effects, of a variety of controlled substances. They then determine whether or not they think hallucinogens should be researched for possible medicinal purposes.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students identify the medicinal benefits, and ill effects, of a variety of controlled substances. They then determine whether or not they think hallucinogens should be researched for possible medicinal purposes.

docs.lead_paragraph: When you pay for your supermarket purchases with a credit card, everything you buy is remembered by the computer, including your name. The information is then sold by the store to marketers who want to target your tastes or to someone who may not wish you well. When you browse the Internet, you may think your visits to offbeat sites are anonymous, but an army of Big Brothers is recording your every click, selling a dossier on you to prospective employers or potentially predatory neighborhood snoops.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column decries invasion of personal privacy by information industry that uses data to target consumers' tastes; urges consumers to fight back by insisting on legislation to protect their privacy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Unicef opened a campaign today against forced childhood marriages, calling the practice a violation of human rights. Children forced into marriages by their families -- sometimes at 8 or even younger -- face a range of problems. Linked to custom, poverty or even the belief that a little girl will be safe from premarital sex, child marriage is most prevalent in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia.

headline.main: U.N. Agency Sets Its Sights On Curbing Child Marriage

docs.abstract: Unicef opens campaign against forced childhood marriages, saying practice violates human rights; says early marriage has profound physical, intellectual, psychological and emotional impacts on both boys and girls, cutting off educational opportunities and chances of personal growth; says that for girls, it almost certainly means premature pregnancy and childbearing and likely means lifetime of domestic and sexual subservience over which they have no control (M)
